intro: Gisekia molluginoides, commonly known as the hairy mouse-ear, is a small, flowering plant native to southern Africa. It belongs to the family Aizoaceae, commonly referred to as the ice plant family, and is characterized by its succulent, fleshy leaves and small, star-shaped flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils and is adapted to arid or semi-arid environments. It produces bright yellow flowers that bloom in the spring, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Due to its unique appearance and ecological role, it is often cultivated in rock gardens and succulent collections.
